msContents.summary: List of expenses given for the Tiruvātirai festival celebrated in Cidambaram. The inscription includes donations of gold coins kācu to Śrīmāheśvaras, reciters of Tiruttoṇṭattokai, weavers, oil sellers, merchants, among others.

24th year of the glorious king Rājentiracōḻa, the Lord, alias the king Irācakēcaripaṉmar,

On the day of the festival of the sacred month of Aṉi organized for the Lord of Tirucciṟṟampalam, master of NakkaṉThe name, which literally means “the dancer girl” already indicates the service she had at the temple. Pāvai, female attendant aṇukki to the king Rājentiracōḻa, his image shall be gracefully erected eḻuntaruḷum.
A thousand pots of cooked rice shall be distributed to the śrīmaheśvaras at the time of dinner amutuceytaruḷum and for the offering of rice donated aḻikkum to the Lord.
Two gold coins for the expenditures including the garments paricaṭṭam and gold gracefully given for the oil eṇṇey used during the festival for the Lord.

The endowment has been previously determined according to the attested copy teṟiṉa piramāṇappaṭi from the town Kuṇamemeṉkaipuram, which states that the land is taken from a section of Parākramacōḻanallūr in the Kiṭārakoṇṭacōḻa-periḷamai“The uḻukuḍi or the tenant-cultivators were otherwise called pēriḷamai”, (according to Subbrayalu South India p. 153). It would mean that this is referring to a Brāhmaṇa settlement which was in fact a hamlet of an independent village taṉiyūr inhabited by these uḻukuṭi. -nāṭu, a hamlet piṭākai to the east of Perumpaṟṟappuliyūr, an independent town taṉiyūr from the current Rājentira-ciṅkaḷanāṭu.
According to epigraphist, from line 7 takkaṇalāṭamum, “the wording is quite different from that of the other published inscriptions”.
